Amid Republican claims of voter fraud in the 2020 election, an image surfaced on social media claiming that a lawsuit had been filed in Detroit alleging voter fraud, including duplicate names and dead people on voter registration rolls.

The image, posted by several Facebook users, was from screen grab of a report by Detroit's Fox2 News. One Facebook user posted the image, with a comment, "Election fraud is real. President Trump is right."
The image was circulated two days after the Nov. 3 presidential election amid baseless charges by President Donald Trump of voter fraud and vote rigging.
More:Fact check: Trump ballots were not thrown out as claimed by fake poll worker
Among the more dramatic allegations from the lawsuit is that registration rolls listed more than 2,500 dead people, including one person purportedly born in 1823, and duplicate names.

The lawsuit, according to the image, had been filed by the Public Interest Legal Foundation, an Indiana-based conservative, nonprofit, public interest law firm that specializes in civil litigation in high-profile political cases.

The image of the TV news report of a lawsuit is accurate, but it aired in December, not during the 2020 presidential election. The group's lawsuit was filed 11 months before the 2020 elections. The Detroit News reported that the case was dropped in June.
According to court documents, the foundation withdrew its complaint after finding that Detroit City Clerk Janice Winfrey and Elections Director George Azzouz had taken “remedial action.”

“Defendants have taken action on the list of likely deceased registrants provided by the plaintiff,” according to a brief by the foundation calling for dismissal of the suit. “Further, almost all of the duplicate registrations that Plaintiff brought to defendants’ attention have been corrected.”
More:Fact check: False claim that deceased Michigan man voted in 2020

The Detroit News quoted Winfrey as saying the updated voter rolls were largely a result of regular maintenance, but did note that her office looked into a few specific claims raised in the lawsuit, particularly one alleging that one registrant was born in 1823.
“We did do some extra digging because that is ridiculous and we wanted to see what was going on there,” Winfrey said. “The conclusion was that that was a typographical error.”

In its motion to drop the case, the foundation said the defendants had addressed the issue of deceased registrants it had raised and noted that all cases of duplicate registrations "have been corrected."
More:Fact check: Typo led to false post about Michigan votes showing up 'magically' for Biden
"Plaintiff has obtained what it has sought — a fix for the list maintenance problems of deceased and duplicate registrants, " said the motion, which was granted.
PolitiFact examined the report and found it "misleading," while Snopes labeled it "False."

We rate this claim as PARTLY FALSE, based on our research, because it is misleading. The report of a lawsuit was accurate, but the posts fail to note that the case was filed in December and settled in June. It was not an issue in the 2020 election.
